valueFormat.notes: Input content with two-way binding support. For text inputs use string, for number inputs use number. When type='number', value is automatically parsed to number. Use v-model for reactive binding. Listen to @input for real-time changes or @change for committed changes.
valueFormat.example:
v-model="username" // For text
v-model="age" // For number input

valueFormat.notes: Determines input behavior and validation. 'text' (default) for general text, 'number' for numeric values with min/max validation. When 'number', shows spinner controls in some browsers and validates numeric format. Use with allowDecimal and allowComma for number formatting.

Controls the visual appearance and color scheme of the input. Default is 'grey'. Theme affects border color, background, and hover states. Use consistent theme across related form elements for visual coherence.

Visual feedback for validation status. 'default' (neutral), 'success' (green, valid), 'warning' (yellow, caution), 'error' (red, invalid). Changes border color and shows stateMessage. Use with stateMessage to explain the state. Critical for form validation UX.

commonMistakes.impact: User sees error styling but no explanation why
commonMistakes.fix: Always provide state-message when states is 'error', 'warning', or 'success'

valueFormat.notes: Explanation text shown below input when states is set to error/warning/success. Critical for accessibility - screen readers announce this message. Keep messages concise but informative. Examples: 'Email is required', 'Password must be 8+ characters', 'Username is available'.

Shows text or icon before the input field. Used for currency symbols ($, €), units (kg, cm), or context indicators. When true, displays prefixText value. For interactive prefix, use actionablePrefixStatus with prefixDropdownOptions.

Text displayed before input when prefixStatus=true. Common uses: currency symbols ($, €, £), percentage (%), units (kg, m, cm), protocol (https://). Keep short (1-4 characters). For dynamic/selectable prefix, use actionablePrefixStatus instead.

Converts prefix into an interactive dropdown selector. Requires prefixDropdownOptions to define available choices. Use for: currency switcher ($, €, £), unit selector (kg, lb), protocol picker (http://, https://). Emits @prefixClick with selected value.

commonMistakes.impact: Dropdown is empty or shows default placeholder
commonMistakes.fix: Always provide :prefix-dropdown-options array when actionablePrefixStatus is true

valueFormat.notes: Dropdown options when actionablePrefixStatus=true. Each option needs 'text' (display) and 'value' (selected value). Optional 'selectionType' for single/multi select. Example use cases: currency selector, unit converter, protocol picker. Listen to @prefixClick to get selected value.
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ text: string; value: string | number; selectionType?: 'single' | 'multi' }>

valueFormat.notes: Shows text or icon after the input field. Common uses: units (kg, pixels, %), clear button, search icon. When true, displays suffixText value. For interactive suffix (like clear button), use actionableSuffixStatus with suffixDropdownOptions.

Text displayed after input when suffixStatus=true. Common uses: measurement units (px, kg, cm), percentage (%), rate indicators (/month). Keep concise. For clickable actions (clear, search), use actionableSuffixStatus instead.

Converts suffix into an interactive dropdown or button. Requires suffixDropdownOptions. Use for: unit selector (kg/lb/g), clear button, action triggers. More common than actionablePrefix. Emits @suffixClick with selected value or action.

Dropdown options when actionableSuffixStatus=true. Each option needs 'text' (display) and 'value'. Common patterns: unit converter (kg→lb), time selector (minutes/hours), clear action. Listen to @suffixClick to handle selection.
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ text: string; value: string | number; selectionType?: 'single' | 'multi' }>

leftIconStatus.description: Show icon on left side of input

valueFormat.notes: Displays icon before input text (after prefix if exists). Common uses: search icon, user icon, lock icon for password. When true, shows leftIconName icon. Icon is clickable and emits @leftIconClick. Use for visual context or actions.

Icon identifier from Design System icon library. Default is 'search'. Common icons: 'search', 'user', 'mail', 'lock', 'phone'. Icon becomes clickable button when leftIconStatus=true. Emits @leftIconClick when clicked. Check icon library for available names.
valueFormat.example:
left-icon-name="user" // User icon
left-icon-name="mail" // Email icon

rightIconStatus.description: Show icon on right side of input

valueFormat.notes: Displays icon after input text (before suffix if exists). More common than leftIcon. Common uses: password visibility toggle, clear button, info tooltip, validation checkmark. When true, shows rightIconName icon. Clickable with @rightIconClick event.

Icon identifier from Design System. Default is 'search'. Common icons: 'eye'/'eye-off' (password toggle), 'x' (clear), 'check' (valid), 'info' (help). Icon is interactive button that emits @rightIconClick. More commonly used than leftIcon for actions.
valueFormat.example:
right-icon-name="eye" // Password visibility
right-icon-name="x" // Clear button

valueFormat.notes: Maximum allowed characters for text input. Enforces hard limit - prevents typing beyond this length. Shows character counter when characterCounterStatus=true. Use for: tweets (280), SMS (160), usernames (50), short descriptions (500). Returns 0 when limit reached.

commonMistakes.impact: Limit enforced but user doesn't see remaining characters
commonMistakes.fix: Enable character-counter-status when using max-character-length for better UX

valueFormat.notes: Displays 'X / Y' character count below input. Works with maxCharacterLength (shows '45 / 280') or characterCounterMaxValue. Essential for inputs with length limits like tweets, SMS, bios. Updates in real-time as user types. Turns red when approaching limit.

characterCounterMaxValue.description: Max value for character counter display

valueFormat.notes: Sets the denominator in character counter (X / Y). Default is 20. Use when you want to show counter without enforcing maxCharacterLength limit. Shows visual feedback but doesn't prevent typing beyond limit. Prefer maxCharacterLength for hard limits.

Minimum acceptable value when type='number'. Prevents submission/validation below this value. Default is 0. Use for: age (18+), quantity (1+), price (0+), percentage (0-100). Validation happens on blur/change, not during typing. Shows error state when violated.

Maximum acceptable value when type='number'. Prevents values exceeding this limit. Use with minValue for range validation. Examples: percentage (0-100), age (18-120), discount (0-99). Validation on blur. Shows error state when exceeded.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using minValue/maxValue on text type input
commonMistakes.impact: Validation doesn't work - only applies to type="number"
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure type="number" when using min-value or max-value

allowDecimal.description: Allow decimal numbers in number input

valueFormat.notes: When true, permits decimal point in number inputs (3.14, 99.99). When false, only integers allowed. Use for: prices ($9.99), measurements (5.5kg), percentages (33.33%). Works only with type='number'. Decimal separator is '.' (period).

When true (default), permits comma as thousand separator in numbers (1,000,000). Improves readability for large numbers. When false, commas are blocked. Works with type='number'. Common in prices, populations, counts. Format: 1,234,567.89

When true (default), sanitizes input to prevent XSS attacks. Strips/escapes dangerous characters like <script>, HTML tags, JavaScript event handlers. CRITICAL for security when displaying user input. Only disable in controlled environments. Sanitization happens on input event.

commonMistakes.mistake: Disabling preventXss without proper server-side validation
commonMistakes.fix: Keep prevent-xss="true" unless you have robust server-side sanitization

valueFormat.notes: HTML autocomplete attribute for browser autofill. 'off' (default) disables autocomplete. Use specific values for better UX: 'name', 'email', 'username', 'current-password', 'new-password', 'tel', 'address-line1', 'postal-code', 'cc-number'. Improves form filling speed.
valueFormat.example:
auto-complete="email" // Email autofill
auto-complete="current-password" // Password manager
auto-complete="off" // Disable

valueFormat.notes: When true, automatically focuses this input when component mounts. Use sparingly - only for primary action inputs (search box, login form). Multiple autoFocus can cause focus conflicts. Improves UX by reducing clicks. Not recommended for mobile due to keyboard pop-up.

commonMistakes.impact: Focus conflict - unpredictable which input gets focus
commonMistakes.fix: Only use auto-focus on ONE input per page/form

valueFormat.notes: When true (default), displays helperMessage text below input. Use for: format hints ('MM/DD/YYYY'), examples ('john@example.com'), instructions ('8-20 characters'). Different from stateMessage which shows errors. Helper is always visible, state appears on validation.

Instructional text shown below input when helperMessageStatus=true. Guides users on expected format/content. Examples: 'Your email will not be shared', 'Min 8 characters with 1 number', '(555) 123-4567 format'. Keep concise. Shows in neutral gray color.

When true, displays animated skeleton placeholder instead of input. Use during data loading or async operations. Maintains layout while content loads. Better UX than spinners for form fields. Automatically hides when loading completes.

Defines skeleton loader dimensions. Object with 'width' and 'height' properties (numbers or strings with units). Default matches input size. Use to prevent layout shift during loading. Only applies when skeletonStatus=true.
valueFormat.typescript: { width?: number | string; height?: number | string; }

basicTextInput.title: Basic Text Input with Validation
basicTextInput.description: Standard text input with validation states and messages
basicTextInput.code:
<script setup>
import { ref, computed } from 'vue';
import { InBasicTextInput } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

const email = ref('');
const emailError = ref('');

const emailState = computed(() => {
  if (!email.value) return 'default';
  return emailError.value ? 'error' : 'success';
});

const validateEmail = () => {
  if (!email.value.includes('@')) {
    emailError.value = 'Please enter a valid email';
  } else {
    emailError.value = '';
  }
};
</script>

<template>
  <InBasicTextInput
    id="email"
    v-model="email"
    label-text="Email"
    placeholder="you@example.com"
    :states="emailState"
    :state-message="emailError"
    auto-complete="email"
    @blur="validateEmail"
  />
</template>

implementationPatterns.name: Form Validation Pattern
implementationPatterns.description: Real-time validation with debounced API checks
implementationPatterns.code:
<script setup>
import { ref, watch } from 'vue';
import { debounce } from 'lodash-es';

const username = ref('');
const usernameState = ref('default');
const usernameMessage = ref('');

const checkUsername = debounce(async (value) => {
  if (!value) {
    usernameState.value = 'default';
    return;
  }
  
  try {
    const available = await api.checkUsername(value);
    if (available) {
      usernameState.value = 'success';
      usernameMessage.value = 'Username is available';
    } else {
      usernameState.value = 'error';
      usernameMessage.value = 'Username is already taken';
    }
  } catch (error) {
    usernameState.value = 'error';
    usernameMessage.value = 'Failed to validate username';
  }
}, 500);

watch(username, checkUsername);
</script>

<template>
  <InBasicTextInput
    v-model="username"
    :states="usernameState"
    :state-message="usernameMessage"
  />
</template>
implementationPatterns.when: Use for inputs that require async validation (username availability, email verification)
cons: Requires debouncing to avoid excessive API calls

implementationPatterns.name: Character-Limited Input
implementationPatterns.description: Text input with character counter for length constraints
implementationPatterns.code:
<script setup>
import { ref, computed } from 'vue';

const bio = ref('');
const maxLength = 280;

const bioState = computed(() => {
  if (bio.value.length > maxLength) return 'error';
  if (bio.value.length > maxLength * 0.9) return 'warning';
  return 'default';
});

const bioMessage = computed(() => {
  if (bio.value.length > maxLength) {
    return `Bio exceeds maximum length by ${bio.value.length - maxLength} characters`;
  }
  return '';
});
</script>

<template>
  <InBasicTextInput
    v-model="bio"
    label-text="Bio"
    :max-character-length="maxLength"
    :character-counter-status="true"
    :states="bioState"
    :state-message="bioMessage"
    placeholder="Tell us about yourself..."
  />
</template>
implementationPatterns.when: Use for tweets, SMS messages, bios, or any length-constrained text
cons: May feel restrictive for some use cases

performanceNotes.description: Frequent validation on every keystroke can impact performance
performanceNotes.recommendation: Use debouncing for expensive validation operations (API calls, complex regex). Validate on @blur for simple client-side checks, @input with debounce for async validation

performanceNotes.description: Many InBasicTextInput instances can slow rendering
performanceNotes.recommendation: Use v-if to conditionally render sections, implement virtual scrolling for 50+ inputs, lazy-load validation rules

performanceNotes.description: Large dropdown option lists can delay interaction
performanceNotes.recommendation: Limit dropdown options to 10-15 items, use searchable dropdown for larger lists, consider separate selector for 20+ options

accessibilityNotes.description: All inputs must have associated labels for screen readers
